abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Petroleum Exploration
            Promotion Project for Nepal was successful. The project
            achieved its main objectives, institutional capacity was
            strengthened, sustainability is likely with adequate
            funding, and both the Bank and Borrower acted
            satisfactorily. Several lessons can be learned from this
            project. First, the need for indigenous hydrocarbons in
            Nepal is great and efforts should continue to be made to
            attract IOCs (International Oil Companies). The terms of
            PSAs (Production Sharing Agreements) offered to oil
            companies should be made as attractive as possible. Second,
            it would be helpful if the regulations requiring a limited
            period during which bids can be accepted is removed. Third,
            the DMG (Department of Mines and Geology) should continue to
            play a central role in coordinating donor financed efforts
            and in finding means of continuing the promotion effort.
            There are sufficient technical personnel in DMG to carry out
            the routine work and their role in assembling and
            reinterpreting data as it is acquired is critical. Lastly,
            funding for technical assistance would be beneficial to
            continue the supervision of ongoing exploration and efforts
            to strengthen the DMG.
